metadata.title: Cryo-electron microscopy structure of the SADS-CoV spike glycoprotein 1 provides insights into an evolution of unique coronavirus spike proteins 2 3

affiliation.institution: University of Chinese Academy of Sciences

abstract.text: The current outbreak of Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19) by a novel 28 betacoronavirus severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-29 CoV-2) has aroused great public health concern. Coronavirus has a history of 30 causing epidemics in human and animals. In 2017 an outbreak in piglets by a 31 novel coronavirus was emerged designated as swine acute diarrhea 32 syndrome coronavirus (SADS-CoV) which is originated from the same genus 33 of horseshoe bats (Rhinolophus) as Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome CoV 34 (SARS-CoV) having a broad species tropism. In addition to human cells, it 35 can also infect cell lines from diverse species. Coronavirus host range is 36 determined by its spike glycoprotein (S). Given the importance of S protein in 37 viral entry to cells and host immune responses, here we report the cryo-EM 38 structure of the SADS-CoV S in the prefusion conformation at a resolution of 39 3.55 Å. Our study reveals that SADS-CoV S structure takes an intra-subunit 40 quaternary packing mode where the NTD and CTD from the same subunit 41 pack together by facing each other. The comparison of NTD and CTD with 42 that of the other four genera suggests the evolutionary process of the SADS-43 CoV S. Moreover, SADS-CoV S has several characteristic structural features, 44 such as more compact architecture of S trimer, and masking of epitopes by 45 glycan shielding, which may facilitate viral immune evasion. These data 46 provide new insights into the evolutionary relationships of SADS-CoV S and 47 would extend our understanding of structural and functional diversity, which 48 .

Notwithstanding the significance of the S protein in viral entry and host 110 immunity, high-resolution structural details of this large macromolecular 111 machine have been hard to acquire. In this study, a cryo-EM structure of 112 SADS-CoV S glycoprotein at 3.55 Å resolution is determined.

Correspondingly in the present investigation of SADS-CoV, we portrayed the 114 general structure of the S protein and the organization of its structural (Fig. 1A) . The size-exclusion chromatography (SEC) result showed that the 138 protein sample is a trimer in the solution and the purity of more than 95% 139 examined in SDS-PAGE analysis (Fig. S1A, S1B) . The protein displayed high 140 homogeneity in cryo-EM screening and was then diluted to 0.63 mg ml -1 for 141 the data collection. Cryo-EM micrograph movies were collected on a Gatan 142 K2 direct electron detector mounted on an FEI Titan Krios electron 143 microscope (Fig. S2) . Following reference-free 2D classification of the S 144 protein, we determined a three-dimensional (3D) structure of the SADS-CoV 145 S trimer at 3.55 Å resolution judged by the gold-standard Fourier shell 146 correlation (FSC) criterion of 0.143 (Fig. 1B, 1C and Table 1 ). The resolved 147 atomic structure of prefusion SADS-CoV S ectodomain covers almost all of 148 the key structural elements, as shown in Fig. 1A except residues 81-101 of 149 NTD and residues 999-1068 of HR-C (Fig. 1D, Fig. S3 ). Forty-five (15 on The copyright holder for this preprint (which was not peer-reviewed) is the . https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.03.04.976258 doi: bioRxiv preprint stabilized by 30 pairs (10 on each subunit) of disulfide bonds (Fig. S4) . The S 153 trimer shows a dome-like shape, with three S1 heads forming a crown-like 154 structure and sitting on top of a trimeric S2 stalk (Fig. 1D, 1E , and Movie S1). 155 The trimer spike has a length of 143.2 Å from S1 to S2 and a width of 111.3 Å 156 and 61.4 Å at S1 and S2, respectively (Fig. 1E) . Three S1-CTDs are located 157 at the top center of the S trimer arranged as a small triangle, whereas three 158 S1-NTDs are located on the lower and outer side of S1-CTDs arranged as a 159 big triangle. This architecture, i.e., CTD sandwiched by its own NTD and the 160 adjacent NTD, comes into being one side of the big triangle (Fig. 1F) . The 161 cleavage site of S1 and S2 subunits locates between residues 544 (Val) and 162 545 (Arg). The central helicase N (CH-N) and C (CH-C) of S2 from each 163 subunit form a six-helix bundle in the core of S trimer. Heptad repeats N (HR-164 N) contains four helices connected by three loops locked between the S1 and 165 S2 subunit at the outside of the S2 stalk, while part of the HR-C is missed in 166 the structure (Fig. 1G) . Each monomeric subunit of S1 contains two major 167 domains, S1-NTD and S1-CTD which are used to bind attachment sialic acid 168 receptors or protein receptors and play a vital role in the CoV entry, and two 169 subdomains, SD1 and SD2 whose function are not very clear ( Fig. 1H-1I , 170 Movie S1).

(H-I). Structures of S1-NTD (cyan) and S1-CTD (green), the putative RBM The copyright holder for this preprint (which was not peer-reviewed) is the . https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.03.04.976258 doi: bioRxiv preprint CTDs are in the "lying down" position, it is not possible to bind ACE2 due to 221 the partial binding sites are hidden and steric clashes between binding 222 factors. This kind of conformation represents an inactive state (Fig. 2H) . The 223 CTDs in our structure keep a "lying down" state, and the receptor-binding 224 moieties are partially concealed. It needs to "stand up" on the spike trimer and 225 release the steric clash for efficient receptor binding. The linker between 226 CTDs and S1 subdomains workes as a hinge to facilitate the conformation 227 change of CTDs from "lying down" to "stand up", furthermore, transit the 228 receptor-binding inactive state to active state (Fig. 2F) . 229 It is noteworthy that stronger interactions in the SADS-CoV S trimer may 230 become obstacle conformational change and dissociation of S1-CTD in the 231 prefusion process (Fig. S5) . Moreover, to probe the intrinsic mobility of the (Fig. S6) indicated that all the three CTDs/RBDs were stabilized 238 in a "lying down" state similar to the structure observed in this study, i.e. the 239 distance differences calculated from simulations and crystal structure were 240 less than 5 Å. Although we did not find apparent expending of the CTDs/RBDs 241 from a "lying down" state to a "stand up" state during the simulations, it did not 242 . Because such a 243 large conformational transition may happen over long time scales (ms to s), 244 far beyond the simulations performed here. Taken together, these simulation 245 results may explain the homogeneity of SADS-CoV S observed in our 3D 246 classification and that the different S1-CTD conformations are invisible in our 247 results (Fig. 1B) . 248 For the NTDs, the core structure consists of two six-stranded antiparallel 249 β -sheet layers stacked together, which takes the same galectin fold as human 250 galectins and the NTDs from the other genera. Besides the core structure, 251 NTD of SADS-CoV S1 also has a loop (residues 133-150) formed as a partial CoV which has a reinforced ceiling-like structure ( Fig. 2I-M) . Based on the 255 structural similarity between the NTDs from four different CoVs genera, the 256 sugar-binding site in SADS-CoV S1-NTD might also be located in the pocket 257 formed between the core structure and the partial ceiling (Fig. 2I) . Compared 258 with other CoVs, the structure of the subdomain under the core domain of 259 SADS-CoV S1-NTD has the same situation as the partial ceiling-like structure 260 ( Fig. 2I-M) . The previous study gave the idea that NTDs from the four genera The copyright holder for this preprint (which was not peer-reviewed) is the . https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.03.04.976258 doi: bioRxiv preprint the structural evolution of SADS-CoV S1-NTD is more likely to located 265 between the other α -CoVs, δ -CoVs, and γ -CoVs. 266 For the CTDs, despite there are dramatic sequential differences between 267 SADS-CoV S1-CTD and other CTDs, all of them share similar structural 268 topology (Fig. 2N-R) . Hence, we propose that the SADS-CoV S1-CTD located 288 between the other α -, δ -CoVs, and β -CoVs CTDs on the evolutionary 289 spectrum (Fig. 2N-R) . Taken together, these results 339 are consistent with that of the sequence alignment. Fig. 3B-3D ) and the CTDs of SARS-CoV-2, SARS-CoV 353 and SADS-CoV (Fig. 3E) . Surprisingly, although SARS-CoV-2, SARS-CoV 354 and SADS-CoV CTD do not share significant sequence homology and belong 355 to a different family of CoVs (Fig. 3A) , they share roughly identical 356 organization and core folding (Fig. 3E) . Notably, SADS-CoV uses the variant On the one hand, the SADS-CoV S has a classical compact structure as 383 other α -CoVs, which uses the intra-subunit packing mode ( Fig. 2A-2B) . As a 384 result, this kind of architecture can maximally reduce the surface area of the S 385 protein to the immune system. Moreover, all of the NTDs and CTDs in a "lay 386 down" station (closed conformation) can further reduce immune pressure 387 (Fig. 2F) . Nevertheless, the NTDs and CTDs still have the chance to expose 388 for receptor binding. FIGREF0.text: MERS) in 2012, SADS in 2017, and the latest 2019 outbreak of human-54 infecting virulent strain of SARS-CoV-2 have claimed a large number of 55 human lives and livestock. They have shared features of pathogenicity, origin 56 from bats [1-3]. The typical crown-like spike proteins on its surface gives it its 57 name coronavirus. They belong to subfamily Coronavirinae, family 58 Coronaviridae, order Nidovirales, and grouped into four genera including 59 alpha-(α), beta-(β), both CoVs infecting mammals, gamma-(γ) CoVs 60 infecting birds, and delta-(δ) CoVs infecting mammals and birds [4]. The 61 genome of CoV is the second largest of all RNA viruses containing a positive-62 sense, 27-32 kb in length single-strand RNA (+ssRNA) [5]. CoVs bring about 63 subclinical or respiratory syndrome, central nervous system (CNS) infections, 64 gastrointestinal ailments in humans, and animals [6, 7]. These infections are 65 accountable for 30% of the respiratory illnesses, atypical pneumonia [3, 8], 66 and show a tendency for interspecies transmission, which happened rather 67 often during CoV evolution and shaped the diversity of CoVs [9]. 68 Porcine CoVs are chief health concerns of the pigs that cayses 69 considerable enteric and respiratory infections causing agents of swine. A 70 novel CoV instigating SADS (also called as SeACoV and PEAV) emerged 71 since August 2016. It is associated with HKU2-related Rhinolophus bat CoV 11]. The intracellular entry of SADS-CoV relies 76 on a precise interaction amid virion and the host cell. The disease is initiated 77

FIGREF1.text: protein is of around 1300 amino acids, has a place with class I viral 81 combination protein, including SARS-CoVs, human immunodeficiency virus 82 (HIV) envelop glycoprotein 160 (gp160), influenza virus haemagglutinin (HA), 83 paramyxovirus F and Ebola virus glycoprotein [13]. The S protein includes 84 three sections: a large ectodomain, a single-pass transmembrane anchor, and 85 a small intracellular tail. The ectodomain comprises of an N-terminal receptor-86 binding domain (RBD) viral attachment and entry subunit S1 (approximately 87 700 amino acids) forming a crown-like structure and a membrane-fusion C-88 terminal subunit S2 (approximately 600 amino acids) leading to an assembly 89 of architecture, i.e., CTD is sandwiched by its NTD [14]. In addition, CTDs90

FIGREF3.text: 100 utilize aminopeptidase N (APN) as its receptor, SARS-CoV, HCoV-NL63 and 101 SARS-CoV-2 employ angiotensin-converting enzyme 2 (ACE2), and MERS-102 CoV ties to dipeptidyl-peptidase 4 (DPP4). However, receptor investigation of 103 SADS-CoV demonstrated that none of the known CoV receptors, i.e., APN, 104 ACE2 and DPP4, is crucial for cell entry that shows the divergence and 105 significance of S protein in SADS-CoV infection [10]. Along these lines, 106 considering the clinical indications of this advancing virus, there is an 107 essential need for primary and practical comprehension of SADS-CoV to 108 expand mechanisms of viral entry and pathogenesis in pigs.

FIGREF8.text: like structure by three monomeric subunits, which can be divided into 200 two packing modes: the cross-subunit packing mode and the intra-subunit 201 packing mode [21]. Our SADS-CoV S structure takes an intra-subunit 202 quaternary packing mode where the NTD and CTD from the same subunits 203 pack together by head to head. In SADS-CoV S, the three NTDs from different 204 subunits are located at the vertices of the big triangle formed by the S1 205 subunits and sandwich the CTDs to the center of the triangle. As a result, the 206 putative receptor-binding moieties located on the top of CTDs are also 207wrapped at the center of the crown-like trimer (Fig. 2A). Accordingly, the 208 geometry of SADS-CoV S resembles the prefusion structures of other that use the cross-subunit packing mode (Fig. 2A-2E).211    Interestingly, although SADS-CoV belongs to the α -genera, its spike protein 212 doesn't have the domain 0, which is commonly found in other α -genera CoVs, 213 e.g., NL63-CoV and PEDV(Fig. 2F-G)[20].214Different from the receptor-binding inactive state of these structures 215 whose all three CTDs in "lying down" positions (Fig. 2A-2E), the previous 216 study captured several β -CoVs S which contain one or two, even all three 217 CTDs in "stand up" positions [7, 15, 17, 22, 23]. The engagement of the CTDs 218 of SARS S trimer helps it to keep one or more CTDs in the "stand up" position 219 and facilitate the binding of ACE2 or neutralizing antibodies. If all the three

FIGREF17.text: between the S of SADS-CoV, SARS-CoV and SARSanalysis based on the whole genome and N gene of 324 eight SADS-CoVs and other CoVs showed that all the sequences of SADS-325 CoVs clustered with bat coronavirus HKU2 to form a well-defined branch and 326 belong to the α -genera [25]. However, surprisingly/interestingly, the 327 phylogenetic analysis of the S genes showed that the S gene cluster can be 25]. The structural alignment of the SADS-CoV S trimer by Dali 332 analysis (http://ekhidna2.biocenter.helsinki.fi/dali/) implies that SADS-CoV S 333 has a relative conservation with that of β -CoVs, as reflected by the generally 334 high Z-scores and high RMSD (Table S1). In addition, the Dali analysis of 335 CTD showed that SADS-CoV S CTD is relatively poorly conserved with β -336 CoVs, as reflected by the generally low Z-scores and high RMSD. However, it 337 shares roughly identical core folding with other β -CoVs, i.e., HKU9, SARS-

FIGREF18.text: Based on the phylogenetic analysis, we compared the CTDs of SADS-341 CoV, SARS-CoV and SARS-CoV-2 by the sequence and structure. The whole 342 SADS-CoV S ectodomain is only approximately 30% sequence identity when 343 compared with the SARS-CoV and SARS-CoV-2, which obstructs structural 344 alignment between SADS-CoV, SARS-CoV and SARS-CoV-2. Especially 345 there is no significant homologous CoV S CTD found in the PDB when the 346 SADS-CoV S CTD sequence as the inquiry. Interestingly, the SADS-CoV S 347 CTD is smaller (about 130 residues) than other CoV CTD (about 170 348 residues) (Fig. 3A). To further investigate the differences between the S of 349 SADS and other CoVs, and deduce the hypothesis of SADS pathogenic 350 mechanisms, we focused on CTD and performed structural alignments using 351 the complexes of CTD (SARS-CoV-2)-ACE2, CTD (SARS-CoV)-ACE2, CTD 352 (NL63-CoV)-ACE2 (

Structural alignment of SARS-CoV-2 (colored gray and red), SARS-CoV evasion strategies by SADS-CoV S 378 As a protein located on the surface of the virus, the S proteins mediate 379 viral entry into host cells and also undergo the immune pressure from the 380 immune system of the host at the same time. The structure of SADS-CoV S 381 provides some hints on the immune evasion strategies of SADS-CoV.

FIGREF21.text: 389RBD system[4]. Based on the structural alignment of these structures, we 390 speculate that SADS-CoV uses the two-RBD system for which the NTD is391 used as the attachment receptor-binding domain and the CTD is used as the 392 protein receptor-binding domain. Upon infecting host cells, S1-CTD would 393 need to switch to an open conformation ("stand up") to render the putative 394 RBM loops accessible to the host receptor. This closed-to-open mechanism other hand, as one of the immune evasion strategies, masking of 398 epitopes by glycan shielding is usual in CoV evolution [26]. Our map shows 399 that fifty N-linked glycans are spreading over the surface of each S subunit.

FIGREF23.text: binding sites are surrounded by glycans, most of the SADS-CoV N-406

FIGREF24.text: 407the putative sugar-binding sites on the NTD are shielded, not by glycans, but 408 by the partial ceiling-like structure on the top of the core structure. As a409 comparison, this feature is consistent with BCoVS1-NTD [27]. Unlike the 410 HCoV-NL63 receptor-binding residues interacting with domain A belonging to 411 the same protomer, SADS-CoV CTD uses a loop (residues 321-328) to 412interacting with NTD from the same S1. Both use N-linked glycosylation 413 (residue Asp358) to make them buried and not available to engage the host 414 cell receptor(Fig. 4C)[26]. Taken together, SADS-CoV has several unique 415 structural features that may facilitate viral immune evasion.

FIGREF29.text: gene was synthesized with codons optimized and inserted into 435 pFastBac vector (Life Technologies Inc.). The ectodomain of SADS-CoV spike 436 protein without the transmembrane anchor and intracellular tail (residues 18-437 1068) was expressed by the Bac-to-Bac insect cell system (Invitrogen). To get 438 the trimer ectodomain protein, we added a GCN4 trimerization tag followed by 439 a TEV cleavage site and an 8×His-tag at the C terminal of the S protein. The

FIGREF30.text: 440 cells were harvested by centrifugation at 4,000×g and remove the cells. Then 441 the supernatant was loaded to Ni-NTA (Nitrilotriacetic acid) resin (Invitrogen) 442 affinity-purified by the C-terminal 8×His-tag. Spike protein was finally purified 443 using Superose 6 HR10/300 column (GE Healthcare) pre-equilibrated with 444 buffer containing 20 mM HEPES (pH 7.5) and 150 mM NaCl, 1 mM DTT and 445 concentrated with a centrifugal filter (Amicon Ultra) to approximately 1 mg/ml 446 and divided into aliquots, flash-frozen in liquid nitrogen.

FIGREF31.text: Cryo-EM sample preparation and data acquisition448    Purified S protein was diluted to 0.63 mg ml-1 with buffer containing 20 mM 449 HEPES pH 7.5, 100 mM NaCl and 2 mM DTT. A 4 µl volume of sample was 450 applied to a glow-discharged Quantifoil copper grid and vitrified by plunge451 freezing in liquid ethane using a Vitrobot Mark with a blotting time of 3 s. Data 452 collection was performed on a Titan Krios microscope operated at 300 kV and Summit direct electron camera in super-resolution mode, at CBI-455 IBP. The calibrated magnification was 130,000× in EF TEM mode, 456 corresponding to a pixel size of 1.04 Å. The automated software SerialEM 457 was used to collect 1,000 movies at a defocus range of between 1.8 and 2.3 458 µm. Each exposure (10 s exposure time) comprised 32 sub-frames amounting 459 to a total dose of 60 electrons Å-2 s -1 .

FIGREF32.text: movie stacks were corrected for beam-induced motion using 463 MotionCor2 [28]. The contrast transfer function parameters for each dose 464 weighting image were determined with Gctf [29]. Particles were initially auto 465 picked with Gautomatch without template and extracted with a 256-pixel by 466 256-pixel box. Reference-free 2D-class average was performed using 467 RELION [30], and the well-resolved 2D averages were subjected to another 468 iteration particle auto picking as a template with Gautomatch. After iterative 469 2D-class average in RELION, only particles with best-resolved 2D averages 470 were selected for initial model generation and 3D classification using RELION. 471 The classes with identical detailed features were merged for further auto-472 refinement with a sphere mask, and post-processed with 3-pixel extension 473 and 3-pixel fall-off around the entire molecule, to produce the final density 474 map with an overall resolution of 3.55 Å. TABREF0.text: The envelope trimeric S protein is vital for identifying host tropism and transmission limits. It intercedes receptor binding to approach host cell cytosol utilizing acid-dependent proteolytic cleavage of S protein by a cathepsin, TMPRRS2, or additional protease ensued by fusion of the membrane[18, 19].CoVs utilize an assortment of receptors and triggers to initiate fusion[12].Receptor binding is fundamental to host-pathogen interaction and

TABREF1.text: components. In light of the structures and functions of these essential components, we detail the evolutionary perspective of SADS-CoV S in 117 comparison with S proteins from different CoV genera. In our study, SADS-CoV S forms a "lying down" conformation following the transition from inactive to an active state, and ACE2 is not the receptor of SADS-CoV. The structural alignment suggests that SADS-CoV S is located between clade. Hence, our results extend the understanding of critical structural and evolutionary insights into SADS-CoV S, comprising the CTD/RBD essential123 for receptor recognition and viral entry. This study provides the 124 epidemiological and evolutionary information of this novel CoV in China, which is deteriorating economically important swine industry, and highlights 126 the urgency to develop effective measures to control SADS-CoV.Overall structure of SADS-CoV spike proteinIn order to investigate the role of SADS-CoV S in its invasion, we aimed 133 to solve the high-resolution structure of SADS-CoV S. Ectodomain of SADS-CoV S was expressed, and purified from media of insect cells after 3 days of infection by baculovirus. A fusion peptide of general control protein GCN4 at 136 the C-terminal end of S was used to promote the protein to form a trimer[20]
